Abstract: Owners of handful of fruit and vegetable markets in East Village agree to allow their workers to join unions, ending bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs; labor organizers hail agreement, saying that for first time, workers in city's ubiquitous markets will be paid at least minimum wage and will receive health insurance and other benefits; they will be represented by Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees; union officials hope settlement will lead to agreements with thousands of other greengrocers in New York, most of which are owned by Korean immigrants who employ Mexicans; photo (M)
Snippet: Owners of handful of fruit and vegetable markets in East Village agree to allow their workers to join unions, ending bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs; labor organizers hail agr...
LeadParagraph: The owners of a handful of fruit and vegetable markets in the East Village agreed yesterday to allow their workers to join unions, ending a bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs.

Headline.Main: Produce Market Owners Allow Workers to Unionize
Headline.PrintHeadline: Produce Market Owners Allow Workers to Unionize

Keywords.Name: organizations
Keywords.Value: UNION OF NEEDLETRADES, INDUSTRIAL AND TEXTILE EMPLOYEES
